args: I'm over here, Mister Solf!\nCatch me if you can!
Hee hee! Over here, over here!
Ha ha! I have you now, you rascals!
Come along, children. It's time for us\nto go back to the church.
Thank you for taking time to play with\nthe children again today, Solf.
Anything to bring comfort and joy\nto these poor orphans.
Farewell, children. Until we meet again.
You can come out of there now.\nI know you're hiding.
You have been staring at that boy for some\ntime now. Tell me what you are after\nbefore I cut you down where you stand.
No, wait! I'll tell you everything!\nYou see, my name is Oswald,\nand that boy...is my son.
So you are here to regain custody of him?
I would give anything for that, but...
There is something which prevents you\nfrom doing so?
When my son was but an infant,\nmy wife and I were traveling with him\nwhen there was an accident.

Our cart overturned, and our child was
hurled into a river at the bottom of a cliff.
We searched frantically, but could find
no sign of him in the end.
But we are a family of means, you see,\nand desperately needed an heir.
My wife took the loss of our son especially\nhard, and I was afraid to broach the topic\nof having another of our own.
So instead we adopted a child and raised\nhim with love as our own, while never\ntelling him the truth of the matter.
But a few days ago, we learned our first\nson had survived the accident and was\nliving here at this very orphanage!
(A true heir, an adopted heir, and a father.\nIt is exactly like Nedrick, Aurelius,\nand {player_name}.)
I never stopped loving my first son,\nand would do anything to have him back.
But if I did that, I would be forced to tell\nour adopted son the truth.
If he knew we weren't related, it might\nwell break his heart. What should I do?
(A father suffering alone for the love\nof his child...)
(Ah, Aurelius, my old friend...\nDid you also suffer like this?)
I cannot tell you what to do in regards\nto the matter of your first son.
But I do know of a man who suffered\nin circumstances similar to your own.

He agonized over the matter for an age.
In the end, he simply did nothing. It was
a choice he regretted to the end
of his days.
The thought of living with such regret...
That's it. I've made up my mind.\nI'm going to take back my child!
It's just as you said: If I don't bring my\nson home, I'll never forgive myself!
Thank you so much, sir.\nYou cleared up all of my doubts.
I am glad to have been of assistance,\nand wish you and your sons happiness.
Oswald's biological son was overjoyed when he\nlearned his father had come to take him home.
You seem agitated. What is the matter?
Oh, you're that man from the other day!\nI'm so sorry, but have you seen my son\nanywhere?!
The son you recently took back\ninto your custodianship?
No, my adopted son—the one we've loved\nand cared for all this time! He ran away\nfrom home this morning!
I can only assume he was devastated to\nfind out we're not related by blood.
I hurt him deeply, and know he must\nresent me for it.
But be that as it may, he's still just a child,\nand I have a duty to take care of him.
Even if he hates me and refuses to accept\nme as his father—and even if we can't go\nback to the way things were before.
...I would not be so sure that is how\nhe feels.
Your son's disappearance may be an act of\nkindness, done out of love for you.
I have seen before how people often\nmisunderstand and hurt each other\nin the name of love.

And I have come to understand that the
reason for such misgivings is the
discrepancy between the love one gives
and the love that is desired.
The only way to resolve this problem\nis to find your son and speak with him.
I am certain your feelings will align once\nmore after the two of you have spoken.
Thank you, sir. Your words calm me.
I'm going to find my son and tell him\nabsolutely everything!
And I will assist you in your search.\nIs there a place your son would likely go\nor an area where you have not yet looked?
Well... Oh, of course! If he really doesn't\nhate me, then he MUST be there!
*sniff* No. I can't keep crying like this.\nI've gotta learn to live by myself now.
I knew I'd find you here.
I told you once before that if you needed\nthe strength to stand tall, you should come\nto this place and look at the sky.

I misunderstood you, my son. I thought you
ran away out of anger—but in truth, you
were looking for the strength to stand tall
and face the situation.
You've grown stronger than I knew,\nand I am so very proud to call you my son.
But I'm NOT your real son!
No. You are my son, no matter if we\nare related by blood or not.
I have always loved you and raised you\nas my own, have I not?
And that will never change, even with our\nbiological son having returned.
So...you don't want to throw me away?
I would never throw away either\nof my beloved children!
Now let's go home. Your mother is worried\nsick about you.
Let's be a family again—all four of us.
(People misunderstand and hurt each\nother in the name of love.)
(But once they overcome those hurdles,\nthey can understand and support each\nother anew.)
